dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Over a tenth of the global fleet, that's more than 850 planes, just grounded right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Over a tenth of the global fleet, that's more than eight hundred fifty planes, just grounded right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over a third of the global fleet of 8,500 passenger planes have been parked, and scheduled flights this week will offer fewer than half as many total seats as in mid-January.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and yet, um, scheduled flights this week are actually offering more total seats than back in mid-January. It's a weird mismatch.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and yet, um, scheduled flights this week are actually offering more total seats than back in mid-January. It's a weird mismatch.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over a third of the global fleet of 8,500 passenger planes have been parked, and scheduled flights this week will offer fewer than half as many total seats as in mid-January.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Robert Stallard from Vertical Research Partners estimates airlines will need 8,500 new aircraft over the next five years—that's like, 3,000 more than he thought just a few months ago.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Robert Stallard from Vertical Research Partners estimates airlines will need eight thousand, five hundred new aircraft over the next five years-that's like, three thousand more than he thought just a few months ago.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Airlines will need 6,300 new aircraft over the next five years, estimates Robert Stallard, an analyst with Vertical Research Partners, about 2,000 fewer than hed forecast just a few months ago.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is wild, because he's basing that on a 20% increase in passenger miles this year? That seems... optimistic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild, because he's basing that on a twenty percent increase in passenger miles this year? That seems... optimistic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats based on an estimate of a stomach-churning 40% reduction in airline passenger miles this year, roughly matching the industry group IATAs forecast, and a slow recovery that only sees airline traffic return to 2018 levels in 2026.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and Helane Becker from Cowen thinks it'll take 6 to 12 months just to get back to some level of normal. After 9/11, she notes it took five years for a full recovery on long-haul routes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and Helane Becker from Cowen thinks it'll take six to twelve months just to get back to some level of normal. After nine over eleven, she notes it took five years for a full recovery on long-haul routes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Cowen airline analyst Helane Becker told Forbes she expects it will take 18 to 24 months for traffic to return to some level of normal. After 9/11, it took roughly seven years for U.S. airlines traffic to fully recover on flights over 500 miles and over 1,000 miles, she notes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But Stallard's still projecting the active fleet will exceed 2019 levels by early 2024. He thinks Boeing deliveries will be up 15%, Airbus up 18%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Stallard's still projecting the active fleet will exceed twenty nineteen levels by early twenty twenty four. He thinks Boeing deliveries will be up fifteen percent, Airbus up eighteen percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With thousands of older planes likely to be retired permanently, with a tilt toward widebodies, and delivery of new planes deferred or canceled as airlines seek to cut costs, Stallard believes the active airline fleet wont return to 2019 levels until about 2025. He expects Airbus deliveries will come in 21% lower than hed previously forecast from 2020 through 2024, off 1,012 planes, while Boeing's will be down 26%, or 931 planes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Though Richard Aboulafia at Teal Group warns these estimates might be too optimistic, given all the uncertainties around the pandemic and government support.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though Richard Aboulafia at Teal Group warns these estimates might be too optimistic, given all the uncertainties around the pandemic and government support.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This and other estimates may be too conservative, says Richard Aboulafia, Teal Groups vice president of analysis, given the many unknowns as to the length of the pandemic, how travelers will respond and the effectiveness of government efforts to support airlines, manufactures and the global economy. I think a lot of us have a creeping anxiety it could be a whole lot worse, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the 737 MAX—Boeing might actually be cushioned by its popularity as a cheaper alternative to widebodies on thinner routes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the seven hundred thirty seven M A X-Boeing might actually be cushioned by its popularity as a cheaper alternative to widebodies on thinner routes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Aboulafia and Stallard expect Airbus to be cushioned by the popularity of the A321, a long-range narrowbody that can serve as a cheaper alternative to widebodies on thinner long-haul routes, as well as pioneer new ones.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Stallard forecasts Boeing's 737 monthly delivery rate could hit 75 a month by 2022, which is eight above their old production goal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Stallard forecasts Boeing's seven hundred thirty seven monthly delivery rate could hit seventy five a month by twenty twenty two, which is eight above their old production goal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Airbus monthly delivery rate for the A320 family could recover to 55 a month by 2022, Stallard forecasts, eight shy of the planemakers former production goal. He sees demand being hit proportionately harder for the widebodies used on international routes, which are seeing the steepest fall-off in flying, and the 737 MAX: he expects Boeing to deliver just 30 a month of its flagship narrowbody in 2023 and 2024.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, Airbus might only deliver 15 of its flagship widebody per month in 2023 and 2024. Oof.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, Airbus might only deliver fifteen of its flagship widebody per month in twenty twenty three and twenty twenty four. Oof.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He sees demand being hit proportionately harder for the widebodies used on international routes, which are seeing the steepest fall-off in flying, and the 737 MAX: he expects Boeing to deliver just 30 a month of its flagship narrowbody in 2023 and 2024.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And both manufacturers are dealing with, like, higher narrowbody output than planned—Airbus from production issues, Boeing from the MAX's earlier success.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And both manufacturers are dealing with, like, higher narrowbody output than planned-Airbus from production issues, Boeing from the M A X's earlier success.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The plane makers narrowbody output has been lower than planned, in Airbus case due to production problems, in Boeings, because of the grounding of the troubled 737 MAX.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, governments are providing financial support that might keep factories producing planes the market doesn't even want right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, governments are providing financial support that might keep factories producing planes the market doesn't even want right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S. and European governments are also lining up to provide financial support that will keep factories open and producing planes that the market doesnt really want right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Aboulafia says it's pushing demand forward, which beats falling off a cliff, but still...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Aboulafia says it's pushing demand forward, which beats falling off a cliff, but still...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Youre pulling demand forward to a certain extent, but it probably beats falling off a cliff, says Aboulafia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And with stimulus packages requiring loan recipients to cut headcount to 80% until September? It's a messy balancing act.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And with stimulus packages requiring loan recipients to cut headcount to eighty percent until September? It's a messy balancing act.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Also likely a turnoff is language in the $2 trillion stimulus package that requires loan recipients to maintain headcount at 90% of current levels until Sept. 30.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—how do you expand production, maintain employees, but also keep output lower than what the short-term market actually needs?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-how do you expand production, maintain employees, but also keep output lower than what the short-term market actually needs?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It feels like everyone's holding their breath waiting for that recovery.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It feels like everyone's holding their breath waiting for that recovery.

artist_script:
On a tarmac, thousands of passenger jets sit idle under a quiet sky.
HostA: Over a tenth of the global fleet, that's more than 850 planes, just grounded right now.
HostB: Yeah, and yet, um, scheduled flights this week are actually offering more total seats than back in mid-January. It's a weird mismatch.
HostA: Robert Stallard from Vertical Research Partners estimates airlines will need 8,500 new aircraft over the next five years—that's like, 3,000 more than he thought just a few months ago.
HostB: Which is wild, because he's basing that on a 20% increase in passenger miles this year? That seems... optimistic.
HostA: Right, and Helane Becker from Cowen thinks it'll take 6 to 12 months just to get back to some level of normal. After 9/11, she notes it took five years for a full recovery on long-haul routes.
HostB: But Stallard’s still projecting the active fleet will exceed 2019 levels by early 2024. He thinks Boeing deliveries will be up 15%, Airbus up 18%.
HostA: Though Richard Aboulafia at Teal Group warns these estimates might be too optimistic, given all the uncertainties around the pandemic and government support.
HostB: And then there's the 737 MAX—Boeing might actually be cushioned by its popularity as a cheaper alternative to widebodies on thinner routes.
HostA: Stallard forecasts Boeing’s 737 monthly delivery rate could hit 75 a month by 2022, which is eight above their old production goal.
HostB: Meanwhile, Airbus might only deliver 15 of its flagship widebody per month in 2023 and 2024. Oof.
HostA: And both manufacturers are dealing with, like, higher narrowbody output than planned—Airbus from production issues, Boeing from the MAX's earlier success.
HostB: Plus, governments are providing financial support that might keep factories producing planes the market doesn't even want right now.
HostA: Aboulafia says it's pushing demand forward, which beats falling off a cliff, but still...
HostB: And with stimulus packages requiring loan recipients to cut headcount to 80% until September? It’s a messy balancing act.
HostA: Exactly—how do you expand production, maintain employees, but also keep output lower than what the short-term market actually needs?
HostB: It feels like everyone’s holding their breath waiting for that recovery.
